citations.narrative:
The outdoor portion of the serval enclosure does not have a perimeter fence surrounding it. The existing perimeter fence
around the rest of the facility has multiple areas where an animal has dug underneath it and created a hole. There are
also sizable gaps beside and underneath Gate 1 and Gate 10.
An insufficient perimeter fence cannot effectively act as secondary containment for the animals inside and can allow
unwanted animals or people to enter the facility and potentially harm the animals within. The perimeter fence must be
constructed so that it protects the animals in the facility by restricting animals and unauthorized persons from going
through it or under it and having contact with the animals in the facility, and so that it can function as a secondary
containment system for the animals in the facility. It must be of sufficient height (at least eight feet for potentially
dangerous animals and six feet high for other animals) to keep animals and unauthorized persons out. It must be of
sufficient distance (at least three feet) from the outside of the primary enclosure to prevent physical contact between
animals inside the enclosure and animals or persons outside the perimeter fence.
To be corrected by March 15, 2024.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, an environment enhancement plan (EEP) has not been established to promote the
psychological well-being of the birds.
Failure to establish and maintain an EEP can result in the behavioral, social, and psychological needs of the birds not
being met. The plan must address at a minimum social grouping, environment enrichment, special considerations,
restraint devices, and any birds that are exempted by the attending veterinarian because of health issues or other
conditions. The plan must be approved by the attending veterinarian. The facility must establish and maintain an EEP for
the birds.
To be corrected by March 15, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The outdoor portion of the serval enclosure does not have a perimeter fence surrounding it. The existing perimeter fence 
around the rest of the facility has multiple areas where an animal has dug underneath it and created a hole. There are 
also sizable gaps beside and underneath Gate 1 and Gate 10.  
An insufficient perimeter fence cannot effectively act as secondary containment for the animals inside and can allow 
unwanted animals or people to enter the facility and potentially harm the animals within. The perimeter fence must be 
constructed so that it protects the animals in the facility by restricting animals and unauthorized persons from going 
through it or under it and having contact with the animals in the facility, and so that it can function as a secondary 
containment system for the animals in the facility. It must be of sufficient height (at least eight feet for potentially 
dangerous animals and six feet high for other animals) to keep animals and unauthorized persons out. It must be of 
sufficient distance (at least three feet) from the outside of the primary enclosure to prevent physical contact between 
animals inside the enclosure and animals or persons outside the perimeter fence.  
To be corrected by March 15, 2024. 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
At the time of inspection, an environment enhancement plan (EEP) has not been established to promote the 
psychological well-being of the birds.  
Failure to establish and maintain an EEP can result in the behavioral, social, and psychological needs of the birds not 
being met. The plan must address at a minimum social grouping, environment enrichment, special considerations, 
restraint devices, and any birds that are exempted by the attending veterinarian because of health issues or other 
conditions. The plan must be approved by the attending veterinarian. The facility must establish and maintain an EEP for 
the birds.  
To be corrected by March 15, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
